http://schema.org/text.@value:
MARK KUBINEC: When we're
making molecular orbitals, we'd like to take
atomic orbitals that have the right geometry
for the problem. You'll have a tetrahedral
arrangement in my molecule, I'd like to have
atomic orbitals that point to the vertices
of a tetrahedron. I can do that by a process
called hybridisation-- taking a combination of the
s and p orbitals on my atom and making new orbitals,
hybrid orbitals. Atomic to hybrid
orbitals, here's carbon with its ground state
1s2 2s2 2p2 configuration. I'm going to spread out the
electrons for my hybridisation process, and when I
take the 2s and the 2p to make an sp hybrid, I'll
take 2 atomic orbitals and form 2 new atomic orbitals
with the designation sp. So I'll have a new
electronic configuration, and that new electronic
configuration will be 2sp-- those are sp orbitals, there'll
be 2 electrons in the sp-- The sp orbitals are intermediate
in energy between the 2s I can continue the process if I
take and form sp2 orbitals out Then there'll be
3 electrons there. Those orbitals are
all equivalent, they point at 120
degrees from each other. And that electronic
configuration will be sp2 now. sp2 with 3 electrons, and
1 electron left in the p. Then I combine that fourth
orbital to form sp3 hybrids-- 4 equivalent orbitals now,
because they're formed from My 4 equivalent sp3
orbitals will contain all 4 of the former s and p
electrons from carbon. So the electronic
configuration-- So 4 orbitals equal
energy, hybrid orbitals showing a slightly different
electronic configuration, but orbitals that have
the appropriate geometry
